questions.text: Arrange in sequence the pathway of production of OAE (Otoacoustic emissions): Outer hair cells Basilar membrane Ossicles Oval window Tympanic membrane Perilymph Choose the correct Answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,6,4,3,5 Otoacoustic emissions are low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer. Sound produced by outer hair cells travels in a reverse direction: outer hair cells → basilar membrane → perilymph → oval window → ossicles → tympanic membrane → ear canal.

Highyeild:

OAEs are present when outer hair cells are healthy and are absent when they are damaged and thus help to test the function of cochlea. They do not disappear in VIIIth nerve pathology as cochlear hair cells are normal. Otoacoustic emissions can be used to assess the integrity of outer hair cells. Otoacoustic emissions are non-linear distortion products generated in the cochlea and transmitted back through the middle ear to the outer ear, where they can be detected as sound using a sensitive microphone

Extraedge:

USES (a) OAEs are used as a screening test of hearing in neonates and to test hearing in uncooperative or mentally challenged individuals after sedation. Sedation does not interfere with OAEs. (b) They help to distinguish cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss. OAEs are absent in cochlear lesions, e.g. ototoxic sensorineural hearing loss. They detect ototoxic effects earlier than pure tone audiometry. (c) OAEs are also useful to diagnose retrocochlear pathology, especially auditory neuropathy. Auditory neuropathy is a neurologic disorder of CN VIII. Audiometric tests, e.g. SNHL for pure tones, impaired speech discrimination score, absent or abnormal auditory brainstem response, show a retrocochlear type of lesion but OAEs are normal

questions.text: Match the following: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A - 2, B - 4, C - 3, D – 1 Wullstein Classification of Tympanoplasty Type I: Repair of the TM alone; no abnormality of the middle ear. Type I tympanoplasty is synonymous with myringoplasty Type II: Repair of the TM and middle ear; the malleus is eroded. Tympanoplasty involves grafting the TM to the incus Type III : Repair of the TM onto the stapes head; the malleus and incus have a defect Type IV: The TM is grafted to the stapes footplate, which is movable Type V: Repair involves the stapes footplate, which is fixed. From the above discussion correct match is option A.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B,C,D are not correctly matched.

Extraedge:

MYRINGOPLASTY It is repair of tympanic membrane. Graft materials of choice are temporalis fascia or the perichondrium taken from the patient. Sometimes, homografts such as dura, vein, fascia or cadaver tympanic membrane are also used.

questions.text: Which of the following test will you combine if OAE is absent in a patient? Pure Tone Audiometry Tympanometry Free field audiometry Speech audiometry Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

b, d A positive OAE test suggests a functional External ear, Middle ear and Cochlea. If Absent , it suggests a defect either in the Middle ear or Sensorineural defect. So Tympanometry should be done to assess Middle ear function and a Speech Audiometry to distinguish between Cochlear and Retrocochlear defect

Highyeild:

OTOACOUSTIC EMISSION (OAE) Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are sounds generated from the cochlea transmitted across the middle ear to the external ear canal, where they can be recorded There are two types of OAE: Spontaneous OAE (SOAE), which occurs continuously without external stimuli Evoked OAE (EOAE), which requires an acoustic stimulus prior to its measurement.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Pure tone audiometry is a measure of threshold of hearing by air and bone conduction and thus the degree and type of hearing loss. Free Field Audiometry provides the clinic an option for assessing individuals who are unable to wear headphones. Instead of headphones, the sounds are presented via a speaker placed in front of the patient. So these are not used in the above mentioned case.

Extraedge:

When are OAE done Infants : Universal screening test for hearing in infants. OAE is done in children up to 7 years, rather than using a subjective test like PTA. If OAE is absent, then do a BERA Adults : A patient presents with hearing loss, first test to do is Tuning fork test, followed by a Pure tone audiometry suggesting a Sensorineural hearing loss. Only then OAE is done to assess the cochlear function. A positive OAE test suggests a functional External ear, Middle ear and Cochlea If Absent, it suggests a defect either in the Middle ear or Sensorineural defect.V

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with a Complaint of nasal obstruction and post nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS following failed conservative treatment 5 years back. Post-surgical notes say- uncinectomy done and maxillary ostia dilated. DNE this time shows patent ostia with mucosal oedema in the maxillary sinus lining. Next best step of management will be-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Steroids irrigation and antihistamine Patient with previously undergone FESS surgery for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and pot nasal drip which is suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis. Treatment will be symptomatic with nasal steroid,decongestatants and antihistamines as the next step of management. If fails, restoration of ventilation and drainage of sinus by FESS

Highyeild:

Treatment Guidelines for rhinitis In patients aged 12 years or older, mild intermittent symptoms should be treated initially with a second-generation oral antihistamine (OAH) or intranasal antihistamine (INAH) as needed. For moderate/severe, intermittent symptoms it is similarly recommended to treat initially with a second-generation OAH or INAH as needed, with the next step adding intranasal corticosteroids (INCS) to the INAH In patients aged 12 years or older, mild persistent symptoms should be treated initially with an INCS while moderate/severe persistent symptoms should have INAH and INCS combination therapy Leukotriene receptor antagonists are not recommended for initial treatment of allergic rhinitis Intranasal steroids and oral antihistamines are recommended as first lines of treatment

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- Macrolides may be used in case of bacterial sinusitis. OPTION C- Biologicals don’t have any role in management. OPTION D- Repeat surgery may be done if medical management fails.

Solution:

Sphenoethmoidal Recess Sphenoid sinus opens into sphenoethmoidal recess.

Highyeild:

The sphenoid sinuses are paired spaces formed within the body of the sphenoid bone, communicating with the roof of the nasal cavity via the sphenoethmoidal recess in its anterior wall. Usually lies anterior inferior to the sella The sphenoid sinus is the most posterior paranasal sinus Blood supply: posterior ethmoidal and sphenopalatine arteries Innervation: posterior ethmoidal nerve and the orbital branch of the pterygopalatine ganglion

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- Superior meatus has opening of Posterior ethmoidal sinus. OPTION C- Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus opens into middle meatus. OPTION D- Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner opens into inferior meatus.

Extraedge:

Structures opening into meatuses of nose Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle's circle Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A male presents to the OPD with saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on and off fever and hemoptysis. On examination there is septal perforation and granulations in the nose. Chest x ray shows multiple cavitary lesions. On HPE granuloma, multinucleated giant cells and necrosis is present. What would be the probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wegner’s Granulomatosis From the above history it is clear that it is a case of wegener’s granulomatosis.

Highyeild:

Wegener’s granulomatosis / Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a rare vasculitis affecting small vessels. Hallmark features include necrotizing granulomas and pauci-immune vasculitis that most commonly affects the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys. ANCA is 66% sensitive and 98% specific for GPA and is present in 80%-90% of the patients with active multisystemic disease. Cytoplasmic-ANCA (c-ANCA) with autoantibodies directed against proteinase 3 antibodies is seen in 80%-90% of the cases with GPA Remaining are perinuclear-ANCA (p-ANCA) directed against myeloperoxidase antibodies Granulomatosis with polyangiitis commonly involves a triad of Upper respiratory tract (sinusitis, crusting rhinitis, saddle nose deformity, otitis media, mastoiditis, hearing loss), and lower respiratory tract (lung nodules, alveolar haemorrhage), Systemic vasculitis Kidney involvement (glomerulonephritis)

questions.text: A patient with foreign body struck at the laryngeal inlet has no cough reflex. Which nerve is affected in this patient:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Internal Laryngeal Nerve Cough reflex is elicited by internal laryngeal nerve.

Highyeild:

The cough receptors or rapidly adapting irritant receptors are located mainly on the posterior wall of the trachea, pharynx, and at the carina of trachea, the point where the trachea branches into the main bronchi. When triggered, impulses travel via the internal laryngeal nerve , a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve which stems from the vagus nerve (CN X) to the medulla of the brain, causing response Cough reflex

questions.text: Involvement of Jugular foramen leads to which of the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue

options.label: B
options.text: Loss to sensation from posterior 1/3 of tongue

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3rd of tongue

questions.correct_answer: B. Loss to sensation from posterior 1/3 of tongue
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Loss to sensation from posterior 1/3 of tongue Involvement of Jugular foramen results in loss of 9, 10, 11 cranial nerves. 9,10 cranial nerves are involved in the taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3rd of tongue and posterior most part of the tongue

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased hearing in the left ear. His Audiograph is given below. What would have been the tuning fork test in this patient:

options.label: A
options.text: Left ear Rinnes +ve; Weber’s lateralized to right

options.label: B
options.text: Left ear Rinnes –ve; Weber’s lateralized to right

options.label: C
options.text: Right ear Rinnes +ve; Weber’s lateralized to left

options.label: D
options.text: Right ear Rinnes –ve; Weber’s lateralized to left

questions.correct_answer: A. Left ear Rinnes +ve; Weber’s lateralized to right
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left ear Rinnes +ve; Weber’s lateralized to right Audiogram suggests Normal Right ear Low frequency Sensorineural hearing loss in Left ear Correct answer will be option A.

Highyeild:

Weber test: Place the base of a struck tuning fork on the bridge of the forehead, nose, or teeth. In a normal test, there is no lateralization of sound. With unilateral conductive loss, sound lateralizes toward the affected ear. With unilateral sensorineural loss, sound lateralizes to the normal or better-hearing side. Rinne test: Place the base of a struck tuning fork on the mastoid bone behind the ear. Have the patient indicate when sound is no longer heard. Move the fork (held at base) beside the ear and ask if it is audible. In a normal test, AC > BC; the patient can hear a fork at ear. With conductive loss, BC > AC; patient will not hear fork at ear.

Extraedge:

Test Normal Conductive hearing loss Sensorineural hearing loss Rinne's AC>BC BC>AC AC>BC false positive Weber's heard in midline heard in bad ear heard in good ear

questions.text: A 6 year old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high arched palate and impaired hearing. His tympanogram is given below. What would be the most appropriate management for him?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenoidectomy and Grommet The image shows a B type Tympanogram suggesting Serous Otitis Media . The clinical history of repeated URTI, poor growth, high arched palate and impaired hearing suggests an Adenoid Hypertrophy. management will be adenoidectomy and grommet insertion.

Highyeild:

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft Cause : Malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections). Often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. On otoscopy, Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus If the tympanic membrane is transparent, fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen. The fluid accumulation causes decreased mobility of the tympanic membrane leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve or type B curve on a tympanogram On impedance audiometry , there is reduced compliance and a flat curve shifted to the negative side due to the presence of fluid. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells . Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. Medical management includes decongestants, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid , grommet insertion , tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy. Adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy may be required to treat the cause of serous otitis media.

questions.text: All of the following are objective tests of hearing except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PTA PTA- The purpose of PTA is to determine the hearing thresholds for pure tones , which are sinusoidal signals with a single defined frequency, amplitude and phase. It is a subjective, behavioral, measurement of a hearing threshold , as it relies on patient response to pure tone stimuli.

Highyeild:

USES OF PURE TONE AUDIOGRAM It is a measure of threshold of hearing by air and bone conduction and thus the degree and type of hearing loss. A record can be kept for future reference. Audiogram is essential for prescription of hearing aid. Helps to find degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes Helps to predict speech reception threshold

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Impedance Audiometry- The primary purpose is to determine the status of the tympanic membrane and middle ear by tympanometry. It is an objective test of hearing. OPTION B- BERA- It is an objective test of eliciting brain stem potentials in response to audiological click stimuli. OPTION C- OAE- Otoacoustic emissions are sounds produced by motile elements of cochlear outer hair cells . It is also an objective tests of hearing.
